name: The Most Common Letter
the-point: 'E' is the most frequently used letter in the English language.

name: Shakespeare’s Words
the-point: William Shakespeare is credited with inventing over 1,700 words, including 'lonely', 'swagger', and 'eyeball'.

name: Silbo Gomero
the-point: On the island of La Gomera, inhabitants use a whistled language to communicate across deep ravines.

name: Language Death
the-point: A language dies somewhere in the world roughly every two weeks.

name: The QWERTY Layout
the-point: The QWERTY keyboard was designed to slow down typists so that mechanical typewriter keys wouldn't jam.

name: Mandarin Tones
the-point: In Mandarin, the word 'ma' can mean mother, hemp, horse, or scold, depending on the pitch of your voice.

name: The Dot on I
the-point: The small dot over the lowercase 'i' and 'j' is called a 'tittle'.

name: Pangrams
the-point: The sentence 'The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog' uses every letter in the English alphabet.

name: Official Pilot Language
the-point: English is the international language of civil aviation, regardless of the pilots' nationalities.

name: Thinking in Language
the-point: People who speak more than one language may unconsciously change their personality when switching languages.

name: Oldest Living Language
the-point: Tamil is often cited as the world’s oldest living classical language, with roots dating back 5,000 years.

name: No 'The'
the-point: Russian, Latin, and many other languages do not have a word for 'the' or 'a'.

name: The Shortest Word
the-point: The most common word in English is 'the'.

name: Emoji Universalism
the-point: Emojis are considered the world's first truly global language.

name: Esperanto
the-point: Esperanto was created in 1887 as a constructed language to foster international peace.

name: Untranslatable Words
the-point: The German word 'Waldeinsamkeit' refers to the feeling of being alone in the woods; there is no direct English equivalent.

name: Body Language
the-point: Studies suggest that up to 93% of communication is non-verbal (tone and body language).

name: The 'OK' Origin
the-point: One theory is that 'OK' stands for 'Oll Korrect', a deliberate misspelling used in the 1830s.

name: Sign Language Dreams
the-point: People who are fluent in sign language have been known to 'sign' in their sleep.

name: Hebrew's Resurrection
the-point: Hebrew is the only dead language to have been successfully revived as a national spoken language.

name: Synesthesia
the-point: Some people see colors when they hear specific words or letters.

name: Longest Word
the-point: The longest word in English has 189,819 letters and is the chemical name for the protein titin.

name: First Spoken Word
the-point: We don't know the first word ever spoken, but some linguists believe 'Ma' or 'Pa' are universal due to infant mouth movements.

name: Papua New Guinea
the-point: Papua New Guinea is the most linguistically diverse place on Earth, with over 800 languages spoken.

name: The Word 'Set'
the-point: The word 'set' has the highest number of definitions in the Oxford English Dictionary.
